body:
run integration tests
run cpp tests

Hi @merlimat, can you please take a look ?
Did my best for the tests but did not achieve to run the docker scripts.
However, I compilled the source and runned a few tests on a remote standalone without crossing any errors.
I don't think they should be many side effects as I just exposed code from the CPP client using boost and did not changed the default behaviour of the consumer.

@lelabo-marc You can run the test by spinning up a test standalone cluster:  `pulsar-client-cpp/pulsar-test-service-start.sh` 

Then `cd pulsar-client-cpp/python` and `python pulsar_test.py`

I'm not sure it's a good model to have a clear-text endpoint if only a TLS endpoint was desired. 

This could be solved by network ACLs to begin with, to only allow certain IPs to connect to port 8080
@jiazhai or @sijie If you feel there is anything else that should be added, let me know. üëç

run java8 tests
run integration tests

I've figure out a workaround:
1.install the requirements for build cpp client
2.build cpp client, finally make install
3.download curl source build and install, with specific build flags:
```
./configure --disable-shared --enable-static --disable-ldap --disable-sspi
make
make install
```
4.build your go code use command like this:
```
CGO_CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/include -I/usr/include" CGO_LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/lib -L/usr/lib -lcurl -lssl -lcrypto -lcrypto -lz -lpulsar -lstdc++ -lboost_system -lboost_regex -lprotobuf -ldl" go build -ldflags '-extldflags "-static"' hello.go

```
It is quite complex and is there any simple method?

This is probably due to:
https://github.com/apache/pulsar/blob/master/pulsar-functions/worker/src/main/java/org/apache/pulsar/functions/worker/rest/api/ComponentImpl.java#L922
the method `calculateSubjectType` returns the actual component Type `SINK`, but the variable `componentType` initialized by `Utils.ComponentType.FUNCTION` via constructor `FunctionsImpl` in `FunctionsBase.functions`.
@eolivelli @ivankelly updated, Would you please help review again.

@merlimat I followed your recommendation: implemented a new test, corrected the doc and shortened the name of the enum parameters.

However, 3 tests are currently failing but they seems to be not related to the current PR. The python tests are successful.
@eolivelli Thanks for the comments, updated again.

run java8 tests
run integration tests

This is the right behaviour. In 2.3, functions/sources/sinks are treated seperately. Thus submitting a source via source create and doing functions getstatus, etc will not work. You will need to use source commands to interact with sources

rerun java8 tests
rerun integration tests
@srkukarni I think we also need to do this for all the other producer/consumer creations in the worker service

>  This could be solved by network ACLs to begin with, to only allow certain IPs to connect to port 8080

that option doesn't work for us because of security reasons and dynamic ip at health-checker host. if health-checker host's ip changes then we need to keep ACL open for wide range of ips and that something is not feasible for security aspect. So, we want a solution in which broker doesn't listen on non-tls port except health-check endpoint that  is required take host out of rotation. also this PR changes doesn't impact anything except user can have option to configure broker to listen on separate port for health-status endpoint.

rerun integration tests
rerun java8 tests

@merlimat 
> The timeout should be applied automatically to all the tests by testng.. though this will not hurt in any case

I don't think that is working.. I have seen more than 5 jobs that ran for more than > 200 minutes and then entire job timed out.
eg:  check this [job](https://builds.apache.org/job/pulsar_precommit_java8/6796/console) that's hung at `PulsarWorkerAssignmentTest` for > 1 hour
```
org.apache.pulsar.websocket.proxy.v1.V1_ProxyAuthenticationTest
2019-03-01\T\18:46:28.177 [INFO] Running org.apache.pulsar.functions.worker.PulsarWorkerAssignmentTest
```

```
2019-03-01\T\18:46:09.709 [INFO] Running org.apache.pulsar.websocket.proxy.v1.V1_ProxyAuthenticationTest
2019-03-01\T\18:46:27.316 [INFO] Tests run: 4, Failures: 0, Errors: 0, Skipped: 0, Time elapsed: 17.596 s - in org.apache.pulsar.websocket.proxy.v1.V1_ProxyAuthenticationTest
2019-03-01\T\18:46:28.177 [INFO] Running org.apache.pulsar.functions.worker.PulsarWorkerAssignmentTest
Build timed out (after 200 minutes). Marking the build as aborted.
Build was aborted
Archiving artifacts
Recording test results
```

With all the refactoring is very difficult to see what's the real fix in this PR.

There are no refactoring Intellij is cleaning redundant code and imports when I edit files. It won't cause any functional change in the code. 

I have removed all references to getAddress with "localhost" string for test files only.

rerun integration tests
rerun java8 tests
@sijie @jiazhai or @cckellogg I guess this could be merged then.
I know these are automated but still are not relevant to the fix in this pr

@ConcurrencyPractitioner will merge when the Ci passed.

Hi @jiazhai , I'd like to work on this. I just want to know how can we get the partitions for those matched topics, which can be used to construct TopicPartition like ```subscribe(Collection<String> topics, ConsumerRebalanceListener callback)``` did. Could you please give me some hints ?
This potentially fails applications who use schema in productions :-(

run java8 tests
run cpp tests

Document of canal has been updated here https://github.com/apache/pulsar/pull/3664.
https://github.com/apache/pulsar/blob/master/site2/website/versioned_docs/version-2.3.0/io-cdc-canal.md

@liketic 

I am not sure you need to get the partitions. Because pulsar client already handles that. 

If you want to subscribe to a list of topics, you can do that in ConsumerBuilder to set a list of topics.

Hope this clarify your questions.
@rsamo interesting, can you tell a bit more about the bookie identifiers you are using? e.g. bookie1. Is this bookie identifier an ip address or a hostname?

@sijie we are using IP:Port as our identifiers. 

Example:
127.0.0.1:3181
127.0.0.2:3181
Etc...

Is that the desired way to identify the bookies? We used the IP:Port because the broker logs reference the bookies in that manner.
Ok, so I ran the failing test from Jenkins (```BrokerServiceLookupTest#testWebserviceServiceTls```) on local with my change. It passed, so I guess it's just flaking.
